componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Intercontinental Exchange First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Loeffler. Please go ahe
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to the Intercontinental Exchange First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Kelly Loeffler. Please go ahead.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. ICE's first quarter 2016 earnings release and presentation can be found on both the homepage and the Investors Section of theice.com. These items will be archived and our call will be available for replay. Today's call may contain forward-lo
componenttext:
Good morning. ICE's first quarter 2016 earnings release and presentation can be found on both the homepage and the Investors Section of theice.com. These items will be archived and our call will be available for replay. Today's call may contain forward-looking statements. These statements, which we undertake no obligation to update, represent our current judgment and are subject to risk assumptions and uncertainties. For a description of the risks that could cause our results to differ materially from those described in forward-looking statements, please effort to our 2015 Form 10-K. 
In our earnings supplement, we refer to certain non-GAAP measures, including adjusted income, adjusted operating margin, expenses, EPS, EBITDA and tax rate. We believe our non-GAAP measures are more reflective of our cash operations and core business performance. You'll find our reconciliation to the equivalent GAAP terms in the earnings materials and explanation of why we deem this information to be meaningful as well as how management uses these measures. When used on this call, net revenue refers to revenue net of transaction-based expenses, and adjusted net earnings refers to adjusted diluted earnings per share. 
With us on call this morning are Jeff Sprecher, Chairman and CEO; Scott Hill, Chief Financial Officer; and Chuck Vice, President and Chief Operating Officer. I will now turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As Kelly mentioned, the slides to which we will refer this morning can also be found on the ICE homepage. I'll begin on Slide 4 of that presentation where you will see that we d
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. As Kelly mentioned, the slides to which we will refer this morning can also be found on the ICE homepage. I'll begin on Slide 4 of that presentation where you will see that we delivered another record quarter, including adjusted earnings per share, which was 20% as reported versus the first quarter of 2015. As this is the first full quarter, including our recent acquisitions, unless otherwise noted, year-over-year figures will reflect comparisons against adjusted pro forma first quarter 2015 results. 
On that basis, ICE's first quarter 2016 adjusted earnings per share grew 19% to a record $3.68. Both our trading and clearing segment and our data and listings segment contributed meaningfully to first quarter revenue, which in total grew 5% to $1.2 billion. This solid revenue performance, combined with disciplined expense management, allowed us to expand operating margins by 5 points to 59%. Equally important, these results help generate strong operating cash flows, which enabled us to pay over $100 million in dividend, up 14% from the fourth quarter, while also allowing us to significantly reduce our leverage, which stood atr only 2.5x just 3 months post the closing of interactive data transaction. 
Moving to Slide 5, you will see the component of our strong earnings growth. Revenue growth of 5%, combined with a 6% decline in adjusted operating expenses, generated adjusted operating income growth of 14%. Net income attributable to ICE grew 18%, and we delivered our seventh consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings growth. We achieved these strong results despite a challenging quarter for institutional trading debts, continued regulatory change and while executing on a range of strategic initiatives, from the integration of previously acquired companies and continued product and technology innovation to evaluations of additional value-enhancing M&A opportunities. 
We remain committed to generating strong financial performance in the current period even as we develop strategies to enhance our returns on investment in the future. 
Turning now to Slide 6. I'll talk to our new segment reporting. First quarter consolidated revenues increased 5% year-over-year to nearly $1.2 billion. The chart on the left side of the slide shows our revenues were evenly split between our trading and clearing segment and our data and listings segment. 
Turning to the table on the right side of the slide, you will note a similar balance of growth across the diverse line items that constitute each segment. For example, as shown on the table, total trading in clearing segment revenue grew 4% year-to-year with solid contributions from both commodities and financials, which grew 5% and 4%, respectively. Within those balance results, Sugar, LIBOR and U.S. cash equities each grew double digits. Our data and listings segment revenues grew 5% in the first quarter. Our pricing and analytics revenues were up 6% and exchange data revenues were up 9%, both driven primarily by new users and new products. As these results demonstrate, we are already seeing expected acceleration in the growth of the legacy interactive data pricing reference data business. This strong start further supports our confidence in our data revenues can grow 6% to 7% on a pro forma basis for the full year 2016. 
Finally, listings revenues grew 3% over the prior first quarter despite a quiet IPO environment. The growth in the first quarter and our confidence in our listings business will continue to grow throughout 2016 is due to our clear leadership in capital raising activity at the NYSE over the last few years. And I'm pleased to say that we've already seen a handful of IPOs early in Q2, and our pipeline continues to build. 
Let's shift to Slide 7 where I'll cover our disciplined expense management and provide update on expense guidance and synergies. First quarter adjusted operating expenses declined 6% year-over-year to $476 million and pro forma operating margin expanded by 5 points. Our first quarter expenses included higher-than-usual M&A related spending, but that was largely offset by some 2015 credits in compensation and professional services. The period also benefited from the release of roughly $11 million of nonincome tax-related results, which were partially offset by few 3 nonoperating expenses below the operating income line. 
More importantly, even adjusting for these impacts, we would have been below our expense guidance as we once again realized synergies sooner than expected. This strong first quarter expense performance and our updated synergy expectations result in us lowering our full year expense guidance to between $1.97 billion and $2.0 billion. This improved guidance reflect expected 2016 expense synergies of $85 million to $90 million, that's up from prior guidance of $75 million. And this includes $30 million to $35 million from Interactive Data, which is also improved from prior guidance of $25 million. For the second quarter, we expect expenses in the range of $495 million to $505 million. The second quarter will be first one to reflect the full impact of 2016 compensation increases, and we will also see a pickup in investments related to business development and CapEx.
I'll conclude my remarks on Slide 8 with a review of our solid cash generation, improving leverage profile and ongoing capital return. We generated nearly $600 million of operating cash flow during the first quarter, which enabled us to invest in growth even as we reduced our debt by over $500 billion and returned over $100 million to our shareholders through dividends. As a result of our strong cash flow generation, we've reduced our adjusted debt-to-EBITDA from 2.8x at the end of 2015 to 2.5x at the end of the first quarter. We now believe, we can reduce our leverage below 2x by early next year, which we think is sufficient to maintain our current debt rating, while also creating more flexibility for additional capital returns. We also increased our first quarter dividend payout by 14% versus the fourth quarter consistent with our commitment to grow the dividend as we grow our earnings. 
Our record first quarter results show our continued focus and execution across our businesses. We delivered solid revenue growth, strong operating margin expansion and once again double-digit earnings growth. And importantly, we see strong demand from our customers and encouraging parents are close to market we serve. I'll be happy to take your questions during Q&A, but for now, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott. And good morning to everybody on the call. The first quarter of 2016 was the best quarter in our company's history for both revenue and earnings. And it was our 7th consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings growth. We delivered 20% ea
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott. And good morning to everybody on the call. The first quarter of 2016 was the best quarter in our company's history for both revenue and earnings. And it was our 7th consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings growth. We delivered 20% earnings per share growth in the quarter as a result of expanding our revenues and reducing expenses and while making investments for long-term growth. These strong results demonstrate our consistent focus on increasing our top line, expense discipline, cash flow generation, returns on invested capital and our capital returns. This morning, we announced our decision to end our current review of a potential offer for the London Stock Exchange group. We thought that the combination may have a compelling rational, including bringing together the premier transatlantic capital raising values, offering complementary interest rate and financial products and providing widespread equity, LIBOR and fixed income indices together with extensive market data. 
So over the last year, members of our board and our advisors attempted unsuccessfully to arrange meetings through the LAC Chairman to discuss these ideas. Then following our public expression in March of interest under the U.K. takeover code, the LAC Chairman and CEO these not engage with ICE. Not withstanding, we spent the last 2 months reviewing the data that we were provided with our financial advisers, auditors and legal and regulatory experts to determine whether our operations, expense basis and governance structure would result in a strategic combination that would meet ICE's return on investment thresholds, while operating shareholders meaningful share price premium. 
The disappointing level of engagement at the ultimately did not allow us to make a complete determination of the integration benefit and the related risk that ICE would required to support a bit. We are committed to building on our track record of creating shareholder value by achieving the targets that we set at the outset of our strategic transactions. Because we were unable to establish to our satisfaction, the financial models, risk undertakings and integration plans needed to set such targets, returning our focus to other opportunities to build on our track record of growth. 
As our results today show, our deliberation did not get in the way of ICE growing its revenues, increasing synergies, reducing expenses, utilizing our strong cash flows to delever and increasing our dividend. I am proud that our team has once again delivered strong operational results and the best quarter in our history even as we considered strategy opportunities.
And I'll now highlight some of the opportunities set that we have starting on Slide 9. Our team has driven our range of new initiatives in recent months. From launching our Singapore Exchange in clearing houses to introducing new equities trading platforms and issuer services at NYSE to expanding our data valuation network businesses. Each of these initiatives is on track, thanks to our global team that drive these efforts. 
So let's start with data, which is our most recent area of expansion. It's worth noting that 10 years ago, in 2006, 11% of our consolidated revenues were derived from market data. Today, 41% of our revenues are from our data business where the breadth of our product and services continued to expand. We are already seeing the benefits of enhancing the consistency of our revenues with solid margin and growth profile the subscription revenues bring. We've long seen the trend of data and connectivity consumption as markets became more automated, regulated and clear. And we've been an early mover in addressing the rising demand for information and analytics across virtually all asset classes. This is similar to our recognition of clearing becoming a centerpiece of market infrastructure a decade ago. And I'd like to note that even today, the category of exchange data, which is our traditional proprietary data, is still 11% of our significantly expanded total revenue base. And it continues to grow alongside of our highly complementary trading and clearing businesses. 
We previously discussed the secular drivers of rising data demand, including regulatory reform, automation, unbundling, fragmentation and the move towards indexation just to name a few. These secular trends are also driving growth in the other recent additions to our data business, pricing and analytics, desktops and connectivity. Our acquisitions over the last 3 years, including NYSE Euronext, SuperDerivatives, Interactive Data and Trayport bring a unique range of assets to support our growth. Our new services range from real-time bond pricing and indices to global infrastructure for exchange and broker connectivity to widely disputed desktops. 
We continue to make great progress on the advancement of Interactive Data since its closing in December. Last month, we launched the ICE U.S. Treasury industries to leverage a index business that was part of the NYSE with the capabilities we found at Interactive Data. And we're in the process of aligning our global sales and shared services teams to better serve our customers and realize efficiencies. 
Moving now to Slide 10, I will note that growth in our global markets and clearing houses continues. Just as with data, there are similar secular growth opportunities as the markets continue to evolve. Customers are increasingly adopting hedging practices as well as more recently seeking those solutions to do so in the most capital efficient manner. And hedging is needed regardless of price levels of commodities. Nearly 2 years ago, when oil prices began falling, many suggested that trading and clearing volumes would decline with crisis. The reality is just the opposite, because absolute price levels tend not to drive risk management activities, volatility does. 
In our global oil and agricultural products, we have seen consistent demand for the risk management that our exchanges and clearing houses clearinghouses offer. Our quarter benchmark contracts continued their growth and innovation, for example, ICE Brent Futures, set volume, revenue and open interest records in the quarter and spawn the launch of a Brent contract to better serve our Asian customers at ICE Futures Singapore. Growth in our agricultural markets were once again lead by our Sugar contract with revenue up 17% over the prior first quarter. 
Our financial markets ranging from European rates to global index benchmarks to credit markets, also, continued to strengthen. In our Euribor contract, which is Europe's short-term interest-rate benchmark revenue increased 34% year-to-year on Central Bank actions and the dynamics around the euro, pound and dollar. Volume in our equity index complex across MSCI and Russell grew over the prior first quarter. Consistent with our cash equities and option markets, we're voluntarily continued to drive growth. 
I'll wrap up our strategic highlights on Slide 11 with an update on our achievements at the New York Stock Exchange where we are delivering on the synergies that we promised as well as driving new revenue growth. Our investment in new systems, coupled with simplifying our offerings, continues to create a better market structure for market participants. In U.S. cash equities, we had a record quarter with strong volume and market share that continue to grow coupled with strong revenue capture. We lead an EPP listings with 82% of the new assets under management choosing the list with NYSE this quarter. And we maintained listings from 92% of our U.S. assets under management. We continue to be the the premier listing venue due to our liquidity, tight bid ask spreads and the security trade at the national best bid and offer price on our exchange. 
We're working closely with ETP issuers to help enable their ongoing innovation to grow this investment category. In our NYSE listings business, revenue grew despite the quite quarter for IPOs. And we have great momentum with an IPO pipeline that began to open up in April. We are expanding our issuer services and rolling our new NYSE connect platform to all listed companies later this month. These services are an important part of value proposition that we've been power listed companies and these are not revenue light item for us, but part of what drives our leadership in listings. There remains no more trusted model for our issuers, which is why the NYSE is growing with the first quarter representing the best quarter in its 224-year history. 
I'll close on Slide 12, noting our track record of growth, execution and results. This year has already been a product one, just one quarter in. We've reviewed and chose not to pursue the transaction. We grew revenues, reduced expenses and increase synergies. We continue to expand margins and roll double-digit earnings growth, and we invested for growth. We paid debt and returned dividend capital. So I'd like to thank our customers for their business and what was the best quarter in our company's history. And I'd like to thank our team for their continued hardwork. My colleagues and I look forward to continue to update you on our progress throughout the year. And with that, I will now turn the call back to our operator, Rocco, who will be glad to turn you on so that we can take your questions.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Carrier of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Michael Carrier of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, just given announcement today, looking at growth initiatives that are in front of you. Just wanted to focus on that, and I think, the clearing side of business. Looks like you're seeing some good traction in the outlook for that 6% to 7% growth. Jus
componenttext: Jeff, just given announcement today, looking at growth initiatives that are in front of you. Just wanted to focus on that, and I think, the clearing side of business. Looks like you're seeing some good traction in the outlook for that 6% to 7% growth. Just wanted to get indication. You mentioned new users driving some of that. I know you guys have been active on producing new products and services. But any indication of what's driving that, where you are seeing that increased demand. I know there's a lot of regulatory changes whether it's on the banks are on their clients in terms of trying to figuring out how to hedge, how to clear during this kind of dynamic and changing landscape. So just wanted to get a sense of where you see that plan out and any incremental granularity that you can provide?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start and then I'm going to ask Scott to give you a little more detail behind the numbers. But when you step back, one of the changes that I noted at ICE is that we acquire Creditex, Creditex had a platform that was once called, Today it's ca
componenttext: Sure. Let me start and then I'm going to ask Scott to give you a little more detail behind the numbers. But when you step back, one of the changes that I noted at ICE is that we acquire Creditex, Creditex had a platform that was once called, Today it's called ICE Connect that was connected to hundreds of buyside participants. And we continues to grow that connectivity since we acquired the first and use that the link to buyside to our clearing houses. Then when we acquired SuperDerivatives, and ultimately, Interactive Data, we acquired sales team that had even more connection to the buyside. And at the New York Stock Exchange, every quarter, we have large quarterly meetings with significant buyside participants that I also attend as well as many of my colleagues. So what is happened in our company is that we have been able to broaden our footprint and our touch points to ultimate end-users, and they are the ones that are really driving the growth of moral screens and more consumption of information.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think, we tried in our data and listings segment to break out the revenue lines to give you a perspective along the line to what Jeff described. If you've noticed in the quarter, our desktop and connectivity revenues were up 3%. And that more people
componenttext: And I think, we tried in our data and listings segment to break out the revenue lines to give you a perspective along the line to what Jeff described. If you've noticed in the quarter, our desktop and connectivity revenues were up 3%. And that more people wanting to get connected to us. And once they're connected to us that allows them to consume the data products that we're sailing in the breadth of the offering that we've got continues to grow and that translates up into what pricing business that grew 6% and our exchange business that grew 9%. I talk to you over the years and I look at it every single month, what's going on with a number of users around our exchanges and that tends to be driven by what's going on in the global markets or the commodity markets generally. And that line is continue to trend up. But now by being able to supplement that with the business that we bought Interactive Data to offer more products through a seemless and secure connection that combination gives us the confidence that the overall business will grow 6% to 7% for the year, which is an acceleration of what we've seen over the last year or so, and also, versus what we saw at Interactive Data in their history.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. Scott, just on the expense guidance. I guess, lower for the year in terms of the synergy recognition. Just wanted to understand. I think, you mentioned 2Q the pickup that we're seeing just on a sequential basis. Did you say that's more
componenttext: Okay. That's great. Scott, just on the expense guidance. I guess, lower for the year in terms of the synergy recognition. Just wanted to understand. I think, you mentioned 2Q the pickup that we're seeing just on a sequential basis. Did you say that's more driven by just the annual comp and some CapEx. And then, I think, I don't know if there's anything in 1Q that depressed but just wanted to make sure we're clear on that?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. There's a little bit of noise in the first expense. I appreciate you asking it. So it's driven by 2 things primarily. First of all, in the first quarter, as I mentioned, we had a release of non-income tax reserve of about $11
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. There's a little bit of noise in the first expense. I appreciate you asking it. So it's driven by 2 things primarily. First of all, in the first quarter, as I mentioned, we had a release of non-income tax reserve of about $11 million. Those happen from time-to-time. The size and timing difficult to predict. So that's not something we would expect to repeat in the second quarter. And so that would cause natural increasing in SG&A quarter-to-quarter. And then the second part of it is what you mentioned, the compensation increases really don't kick in for us until March and to effectively in 2Q, 3Q and 4Q, you get a full quarter versus 1 month that would push comp up probably $9 million to $10 million on a quarter-to-quarter basis, and embedded in there as well is an R&D tax credit that we had in the first quarter. So the overall those are the 2Q drivers that move you up quarter-to-quarter. My expectation is in the range will probably in the lower part of that range in the second quarter. And then, we will stay within that range trending slightly higher within in it as we move through the rest of the year.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Richard Repetto with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Richard Repetto with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my first question, Jeff, is when you describe the LSE transaction, clearly the frustration out and it seem like you are pulling out of the bidding, not based on the fundamentals, but rather than the engagement that you received from the LSE. So I guess
componenttext: So my first question, Jeff, is when you describe the LSE transaction, clearly the frustration out and it seem like you are pulling out of the bidding, not based on the fundamentals, but rather than the engagement that you received from the LSE. So I guess, the question is, is there any other legal avenues to pursue? Or is there -- what is the U.K. takeover law provide that if the engagement was to allow you to evaluate the transaction like you want to?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks for the question. I think,, the point I really want to make is that we have a history of doing M&A deals and we have a very strong history of delivering on whatever we say we're going to do at the offset. And that's an important metric that w
componenttext: Well, thanks for the question. I think,, the point I really want to make is that we have a history of doing M&A deals and we have a very strong history of delivering on whatever we say we're going to do at the offset. And that's an important metric that we have here on how we want to talk to our shareholders, partly why I think we have permission from our shareholders to do M&A as we have won their trust that we will say what we said we're going to do, and they can count on it. And so when we can't get visibility and don't have confidence, it makes it very, very hard for us to look our shareholders in the I and suggest that we're going to deliver specific amount of performance. And I don't have anything under the takeover code that's going to change that perception. It takes engagements in order to come to those kinds of determinations. And I would leave it at that.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And I guess, my follow-up question Jeff, would be again have to do with the U.K. But the competition and markets authority have announced they launched an in-depth term in-depth investigation into the Trayport transaction. Can you talk ab
componenttext: Okay. All right. And I guess, my follow-up question Jeff, would be again have to do with the U.K. But the competition and markets authority have announced they launched an in-depth term in-depth investigation into the Trayport transaction. Can you talk about that? It's already closed. It's unusual circumstances, but what's your position and does that put that Trayport platform at risk, I guess?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. First of all, it's actually not unusual circumstances. The U.K. takeover works that they have time to review a deal. So we fully expected that review in the way the process works. And frankly, obviously, we are cooperating fully and we believe that
componenttext: Sure. First of all, it's actually not unusual circumstances. The U.K. takeover works that they have time to review a deal. So we fully expected that review in the way the process works. And frankly, obviously, we are cooperating fully and we believe that the ultimately is not going to object to us on Trayport in the way we operated.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Alex Kramm of UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Alex Kramm of UBS.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just coming back to the discussion for a minute. I think, when those discussions were started, I think, the initial review investors took competition is going to increase substantially when together. I'm curious about your view of how you view your com
componenttext: So just coming back to the discussion for a minute. I think, when those discussions were started, I think, the initial review investors took competition is going to increase substantially when together. I'm curious about your view of how you view your competitive position if those end up getting together, which I guess, conclusion. But also in terms of the integration challenges that they might have kind of like the combining clearing houses, different culture. So maybe any opportunity that you can capitalize what these guys might be a little bit redistricted over the last couple of years.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. First of all, I don't want to comment too much, because they're going to go through competition review that's going to open up a lot of opportunity for the entire market to comment on competition issues. And so I don't want to prejudge any of that.
componenttext: Sure. First of all, I don't want to comment too much, because they're going to go through competition review that's going to open up a lot of opportunity for the entire market to comment on competition issues. And so I don't want to prejudge any of that. But with respect to their offering it's been very unclear to us what is being offered. And so I don't know how to react to this. Let me just make 1 point of color about our company unrelated to them. I'm going to be very clear, I'm talking about ICE. ICE operates clearing houses around the world. We operate largely on a common technology platform. We have global customers that we serve. And in many of our clearing houses, we have highly similar or highly correlated products. If it was easy to figure out how to net that down, we would be doing it, because we have every incentive in the world offer the best offering that we can for our customer base. The reality is that in different jurisdictions that are different bankruptcy James and when we just as we saw collapse the way people were treated in the U.S. as soon as the court stepped in and the administrators and the way people were treated in our clearing houses outside the U.S. was very different. Even though, the products were similar, the customers were similar and the risks were similar. And so these things complicate the ability to do passport integrations. We continue to work on it. We've been actually working on that for years had lots of dialogues with regulators and customers on how it might be accomplished, but it is a very difficult problem to solve, because at the end of the day people don't want money in cross-border at the moment of bankruptcy and regulators tend to come in and regulate locally during these moments of stress. And that's just the fact that all of us are trying to figure out how to work around.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Limited color you can do, I guess. But secondly, on the data side just coming back to that. one question, actually one quick one for Scott as well. Scott, the 6% to 7% guidance on data assume organic. That doesn't include whatever you're buying fro
componenttext: Great. Limited color you can do, I guess. But secondly, on the data side just coming back to that. one question, actually one quick one for Scott as well. Scott, the 6% to 7% guidance on data assume organic. That doesn't include whatever you're buying from S&P, which I believe $100 million annualized revenue so just clarify that. And then for you, Jeff, on a bigger picture. You mentioned integration of sales team and it really getting selling products and again. When we talk to management last before you own them, it sounded like they have really been focused inwards in getting the product line right and not really selling. So just wondering where you are in that process really selling again just we talked to 1 bank the other day, they said, they don't even know where the sales person is. So seems like some things fixing so. Maybe, tell us where you are in that process.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Scott. I'll be quick and I'll hand it over to Jeff. The 6% to 7% pro forma growth in the business is we currently own. So it doesn't include any business is that we will own in the future. And it also take an opportunity to repeat what is said on
componenttext: This is Scott. I'll be quick and I'll hand it over to Jeff. The 6% to 7% pro forma growth in the business is we currently own. So it doesn't include any business is that we will own in the future. And it also take an opportunity to repeat what is said on the last earnings call that 6% to 7% for the year will also reflect market data revenues that we anticipate will accelerate sequentially as we move to the year as well.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just question, I think, your market intelligence and feedback on, which is at Interactive Data, they have various ranges of products and have various salespeople specialize in those products, but they did not have an overall comprehensive way of custo
componenttext: And just question, I think, your market intelligence and feedback on, which is at Interactive Data, they have various ranges of products and have various salespeople specialize in those products, but they did not have an overall comprehensive way of customers. If you add that to ICE that has SuperDerivatives, that has people at the NYSE that has other connectivity has our ICE platform. We have people selling, clearing and exchange data solutions. We also have all these various touch points so the real effort is going on now is to bring everyone together so that we have single point subcontracts are our large customers so that they know how to get access to the entire suite of products that we have. And we can see already that that's just in the early stages, and we can see our Lady that does the work that we've done alone around IDC has improved our sales function and has allowed our revenues to grow and we think it's only going to get better. It's a high priority for us, because we really do believe that this company grows by having close relationship to our customers, because the end up giving us ideas and asked how problems and give us an opportunity to create solutions that they will ultimately acquire from us. And so it's very, very high priority and it's the work that is going on right now. It's also part of why Scott was able to increase the synergy guidance, because we really do believe we will have a much tighter integrated team as we go through this year. Hopefully, year from now and we get back on. We have different market about us.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate your hesitation on two of the previous questions, I'm going to try again. I think, it's important. I'll try to ask the questions a little differently. Maybe, how certain do you think it is that Deutsche Boerse get approval to merge, or maybe,
componenttext: I appreciate your hesitation on two of the previous questions, I'm going to try again. I think, it's important. I'll try to ask the questions a little differently. Maybe, how certain do you think it is that Deutsche Boerse get approval to merge, or maybe, do we see a lot of risk or challenge to this merger?

componenttextpreview: I think, at the end of the day, we have no idea. So it's an easy answer to give you. It's their challenge to demonstrate why they should be allowed to merge and will be passive audience in appreciating what they do.
componenttext: I think, at the end of the day, we have no idea. So it's an easy answer to give you. It's their challenge to demonstrate why they should be allowed to merge and will be passive audience in appreciating what they do.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, it seemed possible that Futures business and OTC clearing platform could appear threatening to your futures business. Is there any way to give us comfort that maybe that merger is not threatening. Like these futures businesses are very sti
componenttext: Okay. And then, it seemed possible that Futures business and OTC clearing platform could appear threatening to your futures business. Is there any way to give us comfort that maybe that merger is not threatening. Like these futures businesses are very sticky, we've seen a lot of competition coming before, it hasn't really been able to Futures business. But again, this seems a little different. Maybe, why is this the same thing we're seeing over and over again and not a threat?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, I note that we've been growing our interest rate Futures business in Europe, and it was up 34% year-over-year. So that's a franchise that we continue to invest in and have had a great results with. We compete with other people th
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, I note that we've been growing our interest rate Futures business in Europe, and it was up 34% year-over-year. So that's a franchise that we continue to invest in and have had a great results with. We compete with other people that have already offer the solution that you just described. And so we are already competing against that kind of offering. I would just testing back if you say how many people in the world are there that have OTC interested swaps that are fully or largely offset with Futures contract. In other words, they completely hedged out their risk. The people that do that are not end-users, the people that do that our dealers, people that are offering something to 1 party and then immediately hedging it out, so that they take out risk. That dealer community is under pressure as you, I'm sure, know. It's been shrinking if you look at announcements that have been going on. So it's unclear that paradigms of the past necessarily are going to be the paradigms of the future. And so we are trying to build out our franchise. We've launched a lot of new products to serve our customers, as we anticipate big changes in the way as this financial businesses operate. But other than that, we're competing in that world today and we're doing really well.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the Patrick O'Shaughnessy of Raymond James.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the Patrick O'Shaughnessy of Raymond James.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of European Securities and Market Authority talked about how they didn't see need a 30-month delay for the implementation of open access rules. I was curious about your updated thoughts on those open access rules, and how it would impact ICE?
componenttext: Couple of European Securities and Market Authority talked about how they didn't see need a 30-month delay for the implementation of open access rules. I was curious about your updated thoughts on those open access rules, and how it would impact ICE?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We've been leaving with -- all industry hasb living with the prospects of these rules being implemented now for many, many years. So we continue to get our businesses ready to be responsive to those rules. I think, the way it impacts the entire mark
componenttext: Sure. We've been leaving with -- all industry hasb living with the prospects of these rules being implemented now for many, many years. So we continue to get our businesses ready to be responsive to those rules. I think, the way it impacts the entire market is that there's a goal to create more competition, which you and I mean more fragmentation of markets. We also think that it will be very, very difficult and hard and very little incentive for any third party to start a major clearing house when the existing tier houses have open access. In an odd way, while its meant to stimulate competition at the end of the day, probably, entrenches the incumbency, including ICE, who has a large clearing presence in Europe. So we continue to build out a capabilities in times that clearinghouse to get ready for access. And we continue to make sure that the ancillary services that we provide around the trading venues, where we do believe there will be fragmentation of our a lot of capabilities to our end-users. So you have seen us take on the ability to clear more indices, improve the data offerings, improve the consultative compliance services that we offer to our customers before start on improving our delivery mechanisms, physical products and all of those kinds of things, which will all largely become unbundled as the market fragments and create opportunities for us.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then my follow-up. Can you just talk about the competitive dynamics right now in Futures trading. Obviously, you have this competitor. You have a new start-up there. So what are the dynamics that you're seeing in terms of market share
componenttext: That's helpful. And then my follow-up. Can you just talk about the competitive dynamics right now in Futures trading. Obviously, you have this competitor. You have a new start-up there. So what are the dynamics that you're seeing in terms of market share and order routing, particularly, in key products brand, WTI and natural gas?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, we have best quarter in our history. So yes, there's competition. But clearly, in terms of our ability to deliver financial results, we're doing very, very well, record open interest in Brent, as I mentioned. And so we have very high prospects
componenttext: Sure. Well, we have best quarter in our history. So yes, there's competition. But clearly, in terms of our ability to deliver financial results, we're doing very, very well, record open interest in Brent, as I mentioned. And so we have very high prospects for that franchise going forward. There are always going to be entrance of this business. As I think I have mentioned in other kinds of businesses, people have figured out ways of expanding the market, that expansion, while it benefits them, also has side benefits often times that benefits us. And I think, you're seeing that in the numbers. As fragmented markets in my mind are bad for end-users, they're very good for intermediaries. They create much more capabilities that brings a new kind of to the market that once they lag in all of the various different venues, which drives volumes. And so ICE really doesn't care about market share. We really want to have people that want to value our services and pay is to provide them. And so that's the market that we focused on, which is a subset of what you're talking about, and we're doing really, really well in the market for people that want to pay for services and that's why we continue to grow.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Chris Harry of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Chris Harry of Wells Fargo.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Questions on the synergies. As you guys get through 2016, and we start looking at '17. Can you remind us, maybe, how much more synergies are left to come out at that point and maybe qualitatively when that will come out?
componenttext: Questions on the synergies. As you guys get through 2016, and we start looking at '17. Can you remind us, maybe, how much more synergies are left to come out at that point and maybe qualitatively when that will come out?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: What we said on the last call was that by the end of 18 that we will be largely through the remaining $220 million of synergies that we had to go, that was 150 of IDC and 70 of NYSE. I'll note again what I said then, which is, what is IDC and which is ICE
componenttext: What we said on the last call was that by the end of 18 that we will be largely through the remaining $220 million of synergies that we had to go, that was 150 of IDC and 70 of NYSE. I'll note again what I said then, which is, what is IDC and which is ICE and what is NYSE, it continues to blur. So we're really focused on delivering on that $220 million expense reduction, again, larger accomplished by end of '18. We mentioned in the last call, $75 million of that come up this year, we increased that to $90 million. And so our expectation are raised there. We announced that Ben Jackson has taken over the Chief Commercial Officer, and he and the teams have been with IDC 24/7 over the last 2 or 3 months once we close the deal and continue to make progress in identifying the specific actions to deliver the synergies this year. And they're working on building 2017 execution plan as well. So as we move through this year, as we get visibility, we'll talk to you about that. What I would simply conclude he is, of the 2020 by the end of 2018, we're going to get 85 to 90 this year. And we are very confident that we will deliver on that objective over time.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a really good question. And we've been involving extensive dialogues with the ratings agencies over the past few months on exactly your point, which is the business model that ICE had and the financial structure and capital structure that ICE had w
componenttext: That's a really good question. And we've been involving extensive dialogues with the ratings agencies over the past few months on exactly your point, which is the business model that ICE had and the financial structure and capital structure that ICE had when we did the NYSE deal back in 2013 versus where we sit today in 2016 is very different. Pre-NYSE, 80% to 90% revenues were volumes based. Post NYSE, it was still 70% to 75%. We're now at a point where our annuity half businesses are about hour our revenues, which introduces significant stability end of the financial model. You saw a very strong cash flows in the first quarter. Why you can't multiply that because got our annual listings building in it. We clearly are on track to a number that's going to around $2 billion of operating cash flows for the year, which you will note significantly above where we were in the prior year. Our CapEx needs have grown slightly. And so even letting that out our free cash flow are very significant. You saw in the quarter alone, we were able to knock 3/10 of point of leverage out in the first quarter. And so I think all of that is why I mentioned in my prepared remarks that we're now comfortable once we get below 2x leverage, which we think we can do late this year, or certainly, early next year. We believe that will support our overall rating. And that trading is important to us, because we're going to do the things that are necessary to support it. But as you mentioned, I don't think think 1.5x is that anymore given what we've done. I think, we could comfortably operate around 175, 180. And again, below 2x, I think, we're active looking at ways to return addition capital to our shareholders. And we're looking forward to doing that.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, first of all, there are tremendous synergies across the range of businesses that we have acquired recently and that's really what our plans called for us doing is unlocking those synergies, the revenue synergy opportunities across them. But ju
componenttext: Sure. Well, first of all, there are tremendous synergies across the range of businesses that we have acquired recently and that's really what our plans called for us doing is unlocking those synergies, the revenue synergy opportunities across them. But just by way of example, we launched these new treasury indices at IDC, but we're able to develop those using a very strong team that we have at the NYSE that has very intimate relationships with large ETP and ETF providers. So we're able to very quickly have a dialogue with the unique customer base over their new product sets. Their idea on how they are going to grow that market and what capabilities we may have to support them. Neither company stand-alone on their own. And it was an amazing we were able to pull that together within the first month or so of ownership. And it's paying dividends. Obviously, we announced very quickly the BlackRock was moving some large ETP products on to those industries and now our team is out working with a lot of other providers and users of the industry is to advance and accelerate those products. I'd just make the point to you that much of this data revenue that we are talking about the subscription-based, which gives Scott the ability to have great confidence may need tells you it's going to grow at 6% to 7% this year. Because many of those contracts are being signed our have already been signed so we have tremendous visibility into them. Those tend to recur. So that's the nice thing about that model. So looking forward, we would hope that we are doing good job those customers and that they will continue to re-sign with us. And meanwhile, we take the products that we develop on the road and find new customers for them, so that we can have growth on growth.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that kind of intense competition has been in the market for a while. And you can see the results that we posted, which is, we're doing phenomenally well. When you step back and look at payment for order flow, while it became accepted within the inte
componenttext: Well, that kind of intense competition has been in the market for a while. And you can see the results that we posted, which is, we're doing phenomenally well. When you step back and look at payment for order flow, while it became accepted within the intermediary community around the equities market. Giving equity kick backs to large institutions that have very strong brands and are trying to appeal to retail customers in an era where the SEC and the labor department and others are very concerned that retail investors be given good guidance as to how their money is being handled up. And say real reputational band risk for somebody to step into that It would back the question if somebody create a product simply to generate churn inside of it and get these equity kickbacks or was that really the best listing venue. What I will tell you is that, all of us in financial services are under pressure by new regulation and also just best practices to make sure that we have no single point of failure in our businesses. And the big institutional investment firms are subject to those same kinds of reviews and pressure. So we expect that in that ETP, ETF market that people will for diversity purposes but it's not economically driven. It's really diversity driven. We have such a strong offering with 92% of AUM at NYSE. And you could see in the face of the pressure you talked about, 82% of the AUM that was listing in the first quarter came to us. The reason that such a strong venue is that we have very, very deep liquidity on the exchange the NYSE exchange where we list these platforms, marketmakers, infrastructures are rules set that really enables these innovative and fabulous listings to come to us and know that they have every opportunity for growth and success. NYSE is a brand that is known around the world, and we have been passported into most countries. And so the platform that we can offer somebody in terms of distribution is really unparalleled. And if those things that are driving the listings. I don't believe that payment for order flow is going to have a material impact on this business nor should it. And I also as you probably know think it's a corrosive mechanism that actually ultimately hurts markets. And so hopefully, I'm right and we won't see that is really innovative ETPs that are coming out.
