I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Kelly Loeffler. Please go ahead.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. ICE's Third Quarter 2016 earnings release and presentation can be found in the Investors section of theice.com. These items will be archived and our call will be available for replay.Today's call may contain forward-looking statements. The
componenttext:
Good morning. ICE's Third Quarter 2016 earnings release and presentation can be found in the Investors section of theice.com. These items will be archived and our call will be available for replay.
Today's call may contain forward-looking statements. These statements, which we undertake no obligation to update, represent our current judgment and are subject to risks, assumptions and uncertainties. For a description of the risks that could cause our results to differ materially from those described in forward-looking statements, please refer to our 2015 Form 10-K.
In our earnings supplement, we refer to certain non-GAAP measures, including adjusted income, operating margin, expenses, EPS, EBITDA and tax rate. We believe our non-GAAP measures are more reflective of our cash operations and core business performance.
In the Appendix of our presentation and earnings press release, you will find a summary of our GAAP results, a reconciliation to the equivalent GAAP terms and expansion of why we deem this information to be meaningful as well as how management uses these measures. When used on this call, net revenue refers to revenue net of transaction-based expenses, and adjusted earnings refers to adjusted diluted earnings per share.
Unless otherwise noted, the year-over-year figures will discuss reflect comparisons against adjusted pro forma 2015 results. With us on the call are Jeff Sprecher, Chairman and CEO; Scott Hill, Chief Financial Officer; and Chuck Vice, President and Chief Operating Officer.
I'll now turn the call over to Scott.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kelly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. I'll begin on Slide 4 cover our results through the first 9 months of 2016. Consolidated net revenues grew 4% to $3.4 billion with trading and clearing revenues up 2
componenttext:
Thank you, Kelly. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us on our call today. I'll begin on Slide 4 cover our results through the first 9 months of 2016. Consolidated net revenues grew 4% to $3.4 billion with trading and clearing revenues up 2% and data and listings revenue up 6% versus the prior year.
In addition, operating margins expanded 4 points to 57%, and expected 2016 synergies have increased over 50% to $115 million. All of these factors enabled adjusted earnings to grow 10% versus 2015 pro forma results.
This financial performance also generated record operating cash flow of $1.5 billion for September. This strong cash generation enabled us to reduce our leverage, grew our dividend and, in October, to reach our share repurchase program.
We are executing the well-designed strategic plan, are efficiently integrating our acquired businesses and are delivering top and bottom line growth, strong cash generation and improving ROIC and capital return all less than 1 year after closing our acquisition of Interactive Data.
Now let's turn to Slide 5 where I'll walk you through our results for the third quarter. Revenues in the quarter were up slightly over the prior year. Adjusted operating expenses declined 3% year-over-year and margins expanded to 55%. Adjusted operating income increased 4% year-to-year, and adjusted earnings per share were $3.21. Of note, you'll see that our third quarter tax rate was roughly 30%. We currently expect a similar rate for the fourth quarter.
Moving next to Slide 6, I'll provide some additional details about our third quarter revenues. While our total revenues were roughly flat, our data and listings segment revenue grew 5% year-over-year and represented 55% of our consolidated revenue for the quarter. Within the data and listings segment, our change data was up 17% year-over-year. Pricing and Analytics revenue would have grown 3%, excluding the weakness in the pound and the impact of a large customer true up that occurred in the prior third quarter. Our data revenues remain on track to grow between 6% and 7% for the full year 2016, and the outlook is favorable for at least a similar level of growth in 2017. Our trading and clearing revenues declined 4% versus the prior year as lower volatility and the precipitous fall in the pound created a significant headwind.
Within the trading and clearing segment, though, commodities revenues grew 2%, including energy revenue, which grew 4% year-to-year. Oil and natural gas were both strong contributors and continue to grow in October. Despite continued growth in our OTC clearing business, financial revenues declined 14%, including interest revenues, which were down 15%.
Interest rate future volume grew 13% in the quarter, but revenues were severely impacted by the weaker pound. We expect to publish our October volumes on Wednesday. And despite the currency impacts and lower volatility and equity, we primarily expect reported solid results, including volumes up around 10% and interest rate volumes going more than 50% versus the prior year. The increased volumes, stable to improving open interest level and continued growth in exchange data customers, interest in the markets we operate, remains high. 
Now let's look to Slide 7, where I'll discuss our expense performance and provide updated guidance. Third quarter adjusted operating expenses declined 3% year-over-year to $484 million, and pro forma operating margin expanded by 2 points. Importantly, please also note on the right side of the slide that margins expanded in both our businesses. As we continue to integrate our acquisitions and streamline our operations, we are realizing interactive data synergies on an accelerated basis. We now expect to achieve around $115 million of synergies for 2016. Increased synergies and the weaker pound enabled us to maintain our full year adjusted expense guidance despite the addition of expenses related to the securities evaluations and credit market analysis acquisition. For the fourth quarter, we expect adjusted expenses in the range of $500 million to $505 million with a quarter-to-quarter increase due largely to the addition of these recently acquired businesses.
Our final full year 2016 expense guidance reflects a reduction of nearly 3% versus 2015 and a $75 million improvement from our guidance at the beginning of the year. This improvement benefited from roughly $35 million largely related to the impact of the lower pound but, more importantly, reflect an additional $40 million in synergies realized during 2016.
I'll conclude my prepared remarks on Slide 8 with a review of our cash generation, deleveraging and capital return. We generated record operating cash flows of $1.5 billion in the first 9 months of the year and deployed that cash to invest around $250 million in CapEx to reduce our debt by $1 billion and to return over $300 million to shareholders through dividends. We reduced our leverage from 2.8x at the end of 2015 to 2.3x at the end of the September. Importantly, we remain on track to reduce leverage below 2x during 2017, which allowed us to restart our share repurchase program in October and will support our objective to grow our dividends as we grow.
We remain confident that our solid cash generation will continue to support our strong investment grade rating and able additional strategic investments and allow us to increase our capital returns to shareholders. Our results for the first 9 months of this year reflect our commitment to execution, innovation and value creation for our shareholders. We deliver on this commitment by expanding our footprint to meet the ever-changing needs of our customers in a very dynamic time in our industry. 
I'll be happy to take your questions during Q&A. But for now, I'll turn the call over to Jeff.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everyone on the call. This morning I'll take a few minutes update you on a key areas of investor interest, and then we'll conduct a question-and-answer session. I'll start with the topic of consistent long-term grow
componenttext:
Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everyone on the call. This morning I'll take a few minutes update you on a key areas of investor interest, and then we'll conduct a question-and-answer session. 
I'll start with the topic of consistent long-term growth on Slide 9. Our tenfold revenue growth over the last decade, including revenue that doubled and earnings that have tripled in the last 3 years, is driven by expanding the range of ways we serve our customers around the world. This growth continues with total futures volume up 20% in the month of October, alongside and expanding data business that is meeting the secular demand for more information.
As a startup company, we gain the by fortifying trading station. This market transparency and product standardization and growth demand for clearing to serve the growing need for risk management. And today, as capital and operational efficiencies become paramount, our customers require more of our proprietary information to support risk management, trading and investment management.
Our services continue to evolve with changes in the market, which creates shareholder value by anticipating and capitalizing on change. As the most global exchange operator with over 40% of our total revenues derived outside the U.S., we're moving quickly to leverage our scalable technology infrastructure across North America, Europe and Asia.
In an ever-fragmenting marketplace, we're providing the consistent tools technology and data sources that customers require in order to stitch together the big picture on an enterprise scale. As a result, we're benefiting from balanced geographic, product and customer diversification. And because we're not levered to anyone cyclical trend or geography, we've let our space and growth on virtually every metric over the last decade.
On Slide 10, I'll highlight the strategy behind our balanced approach driven by a virtuous cycle across our global markets, clearing houses, data and listings. Transaction-based revenue can be cyclical, but market participants always require information and make good risk management decisions. This is why we're establishing a new approach for market data for our customers, who told us that they're looking for flexible and efficient ways to receive and respond to information. Our investments in technology that help scale our infrastructure are allowing us to serve customers on an increasingly integrated platform. Following the financial crisis, many new opportunities to provide valuable services have emerged, whether it's increased compliance, the move to independent pricing, demand for information secure to, algorithmic trading or the trends for passive investing, each of these drives increasing demand for data. These dynamics have only begun to play out. An example is last month's SEC's ruling on liquidity, which will require the measuring and reporting of liquidity risks by certain ETFs and mutual funds. Our liquidity indicators product is developed specifically to meet the reporting requirements in the U.S. and Europe, particularly as both the SEC and MiFID rules come into effect. To further build on our capabilities, we completed the acquisition of S&P's Security Evaluations and Credit Market Analysis. These assets add to our portfolio of unique information that spans virtually all asset classes and provides workflow support for the front, middle and back offices. And having increased our capabilities for expanded bond price evaluations, we're developing new types of fixed income indices for institutions investors as a component of our treasury indices. We'll have more details on this in the coming weeks.
We're rapidly integrating the former Interactive Data, SuperDerivatives, NYSE Index Operations and ICE's Exchange Data to form decompensated global ICE Data Services Organization. In the third quarter, we also completed the integration of the Safety Connectivity business with our 7 Ticks Network to be in a position to offer an expanded range of service. We're focused on leveraging our broad product and client service platform to drive efficiencies for both our customers and for our company. We believe we're in the early stages of bringing our complete and subsequent prostate a solution to bear, and we'll continue to update you as we build out an integrated data platform. 
The other component of the segment is our listings business. And while the IPO environment continues to be muted, we had a record quarter for revenue. Since ICE's acquisition of NYSE Euronext, we've listed 18 out of the 20 IPOs that raised $1 billion or more, including the largest IPO in 2016 with a listing of ZTO last week.
As we always do, we're also curating our business lines to stay focused on our core capabilities. So we've decided to sell a company known as IDMS that came to us as part of our acquisition of Interactive Data. This business provides services to wealth management firms. We have also decided to sell NYSE governance services, which operates in the governance, risk and compliance space. While good businesses in their own right, they don't meaningfully leverage ICE's core competencies or have our strong margin growth profile, and so we believe that there'll be more available to others within their core sectors.
ICE's recurring revenue grew to over 55% of our total revenue in the third quarter compared to just 38% in the prior third quarter. Today, the majority of our revenue is ratable and subscription-based, which allows greater visibility in the cash flow generation and which provides balance to thus ecology of the transactions segment. This also leads to less volatile earnings in more consistent cash flow, which we believe is a higher-value business. 
On the other side of our revenue equation, it's highlighted on Slide 11, where you can see the ongoing strength in our transaction and clearing segment with revenues up 2% in the first 9 months. In the third quarter, volume again grew year-to-year in energy, agriculture, metals, interest rates and MSCI indexes. Notably, year-to-date through October, the volume in our European interest rate futures complex is up 17%, and, surprising to many, is going 3x as fast as the U.S. interest rate futures contracts traded elsewhere even with all the speculation surrounding a potential Fed rate hike.  Importantly, volume and many of our benchmark contracts are up double digits year-to-date, including ICE Brent crude, our agricultural complex, sterling, Euribor and our MSCI futures contracts.
We also set records in our emerging contracts such as the ICE -- pound-denominated LIBOR future. This is the first sterling-denominated interest rate swap feature to trade and clear on an exchange. And you can also see the solid trends in open interest even amid a less volatile third quarter as market participants kept their positions open heading into year-end. And we continue to grow our lead in our share of crude oil open interest.
We believe that our continued growth is driven by the global relevance of our products and their exposure to the numerous international factors that are driving markets today.
So I'm pleased to note that ICE clear Europe and ICE clear credit both received their compliance recognition from -- during the third quarter. And yesterday, ICE Futures Europe received the CFTC's approval for its board of trade application. These are just a few examples of how the U.S, the U.K and the EU have worked together to utilize equivalents, rather than passporting, to management cross-boarder international regulatory frameworks.
Our drive to grow and evolve has produced consistent growth throughout market cycles. And anyone that's followed the financial markets for a few years knows that there is continuous range going on. One of those drivers of change and driver of opportunity is Brexit. The U.K remains an important global market center with prudent regulation, a focus on ensuring market confidence and a strong financial services talent pool. we are maintaining an active dialogue with officials in the U.K government to preserve the role of markets in London's future. We are encouraged by the particle approach that U.K government is taking to carefully consider the future opportunities as an independent country.
And similarly, we do not believe the financial market infrastructure leaving London is in the best interest of Europe's markets. Many question whether we might bid for the London Stock Exchange, an opportunity that we called off earlier this year in the absence of sufficient information to establish the value of a bid coupled with our concerns about the effects on the company of a Brexit vote. Because this important asset could be leaving the city of London, we believe that this may create new opportunities for us as a leading infrastructure provider as we see the ability to continue to invest in the U.K. For example, in December of last year, we invested in the London-based Trayport, an operator of important technology that serves the European commercial energy markets.
Recently, the CMA issued a finding that ICE owning Trayport would have an adverse impact on competition in the European utility, derivatives trading and clearing markets and then be we should, therefore, divest the Trayport.
ICE and Trayport are not competitors, which the CMA recognized, so our acquisition of Trayport does not involve a loss of competition under a so-called horizontal theory of harm. The CMA's decision relied on a simplistic assessment of market dynamics rather than a rigorous quantitative analysis. And it also relied largely on the use of conflicted third parties that have a competitive interest in the outcome of their view. ICE produced a detailed analysis to demonstrate that we would not and could not operate Trayport that impairs access. We also offered far-reaching operational and governance -- to address CMA's theoretical concerns. So we believe that CMA's decision under such a speculative and baked theory is disproportionate and will be terrible precedent for future merger and acquisition activities in Europe. Therefore, it's important for us that we pursue our right of appeal in connection with this pro-customer, pro-market transaction.
We're committed to continuing Trayport operations in London, and we continue to operate the company just as we have for most of last year. Now across our entire organization, our focus remains on servicing customers. And we believe that if we do the right things with our customers in mind, then we're serving our shareholders.
Let me conclude my prepared remarks on Slide 12, where you can see that we continue to build on our decade-long track record of growth. This year again, we've grown revenues, met or exceeded synergy expectations, reduced expenses and expanded our margins driving 16% adjusted earnings growth in the first 9 months of the year. We've generated over $1.5 billion in cash flow, repaid $1 billion in debt, grew our dividend, restarted our share repurchase program and finalized our stock split, which will occur later this week. And we're already engaged in planning for a very productive 2017.
And so I'd like to thank our customers for their business in the quarter, and I'd also like to thank our team for their continued efforts in meeting our growth objectives.
I'll now turn the call back to the operator, Allison, and we'll be glad to take your questions.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question will come from Richard Repetto of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess first question is for Scott on the expenses. Looking at Slide 7. We've talked -- you make the point about increasing the synergies related to IDC, and I'm just trying to reconcile the expenses for the data and listings segment looks flat year-over
componenttext: I guess first question is for Scott on the expenses. Looking at Slide 7. We've talked -- you make the point about increasing the synergies related to IDC, and I'm just trying to reconcile the expenses for the data and listings segment looks flat year-over-year and reconcile that with the expenses, the synergies that you've taken out. Just trying to see what we're not seeing it. Is it acquisition related or investments, et cetera?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Rich. So there are a couple of factors at play. Number 1, recall that at the beginning of the year, when we talked about the synergies. We also mentioned that we have about $45 million increase in compensation and that we be making abo
componenttext: Yes, good question, Rich. So there are a couple of factors at play. Number 1, recall that at the beginning of the year, when we talked about the synergies. We also mentioned that we have about $45 million increase in compensation and that we be making about $30 million of investments in our products and technology. A lot of that product investment is resulting in deals like the index feel that we're announcing in the data space, the continued solid product that we've announced in that space. So there are investments there. Clearly, a portion of the compensation go to our data team, who have more than earned it in the execution that they had this year. And the other thing you see very clearly on the chart is we had some M&A spending in the year that tips the data space. As you might imagine, a lot of that is been around that Trayport deal. And then the last thing I'd note is a number of the synergies come through our corporate functions in the first year of any deal. And those corporate expenses tend to get allocated to the segments based on revenue because account that supports the company, they don't support data versus trading, and so you actually do see some of the synergy even though they are related to IDC showing up in the trading segment just because of the way that we allocate. So I think if you take a step back, we laid out a pretty clear view of $115 million of synergies in the quarter, but that hopefully helps a little bit on the dynamic that you're asking about. One thing that I would point out in the same aria of Chart 7, we disclosed our operating margins for each of the segment, and I think that's an important story that a lot of people are missing. If you look at our aggregate margins and got a compare that to a diverse basket of competitors, I'm not sure you get the same do you do when you look at margins in the trading segment that are 50% in the quarter and 51% year-to-date. Compare those to other data companies that we compete with and then look at the trading margins, which include the New York Stock Exchange, 61% in the quarter, and 64% year-to-date. And again, compare those to our exchange competitors that we deal with. So hopefully that helps with your direct question, but I think that area of the chart that you're looking at is 1 I point a lot of investors to because I think there's an important story that's being missed.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood, very helpful. And, Jeff, 1 follow-up. This -- you do a great job at highlighting the trends and demands in market data. And I'd say the team, it felt like the team last quarter was fragmentation drives increased demand for data. I guess, the q
componenttext: Understood, very helpful. And, Jeff, 1 follow-up. This -- you do a great job at highlighting the trends and demands in market data. And I'd say the team, it felt like the team last quarter was fragmentation drives increased demand for data. I guess, the question relates to, you are starting to see at least in, say, one asset class but some a little drumbeat of pushback from some of the organize like market makers, et cetera, pushing back on the increased pricing for market data. So I guess the question is how to balance that? Is that just 1 asset class? And are the trends that you are talking about just overwhelmed so to this pushback for some market participants?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that is the answer, yes, but just to put -- give it some context. It's always interesting to us that a lot of the people that try to benefit from fragmentation of markets and complain about the fact that it costs them more to do business in that f
componenttext: I think that is the answer, yes, but just to put -- give it some context. It's always interesting to us that a lot of the people that try to benefit from fragmentation of markets and complain about the fact that it costs them more to do business in that fragmentation that they help create. And that is what's going on. You look at where you've seen just fragmentation in the past couple of years with a new entrant in the energy futures space, new entrants in the European interest rate space and look at the growth of our complex in those basis. Our trading points have grown and our data sales in those areas have grown. In other words this fragmentation causes arbitrage between markets. It's less easy for people to figure out where the market is at any moment in time. It's much more difficult to write a settlement price for marketing folks. There is much more load,  if you will, on the middle and back-office for compliance, best execution and so on and so forth. All of that trend is driving demand for increased information. One point that, that group that is spending more and more on data doesn't recognize is that the actual cost of data is plummeting. There is just the fact that people are buying more lower-cost, declining cost information. And the spend for many of these people is voluntary. It is because they want a holistic view of the market, and a voluntarily are going out having to buy more and more information even though on a per-unit basis. Information prices have been collapsing over the last decade. So we think the total wallet, if you will, is going to continue to increase. Regulatory pressures, back-office compliance, pressure, reporting pressures, things that all of us in a more regulated financial service industry are going to had to adjust to and pay for. Yes, it's expensive. Yes, it wasn't something that we had to do before, is affecting our room as well. But it is in the irreversible trends in my mind. We still have a lot of regulation to come into impact in Europe, MiFID for example; the differences that may come out of the EU and the U.K with the actual Brexit separation. So I would expect that the trend is going to continue.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I appreciate the question. So the increase to $500 million to $505 million in the quarter is almost solely due to those 2 acquisitions. And so if you kind of back out, you call it $15 million, the guidance range would've been $485 million to $490 mil
componenttext: Yes, I appreciate the question. So the increase to $500 million to $505 million in the quarter is almost solely due to those 2 acquisitions. And so if you kind of back out, you call it $15 million, the guidance range would've been $485 million to $490 million, which is what we've been on average every quarter this year and so relatively flat on a quarter-to-quarter basis. In terms of revenue, you'll likely recall that I mentioned last quarter we see a slight deceleration into the third quarter and then a reacceleration into the fourth where we would approach $500 million of data revenue. That was at a time where the pound was still around $1.31. It's now closer to $1.22. And so that looks softened a little bit. So on an apples-to-apples basis, versus maybe the high 4 90s, we'd be looking closer to the low to mid 4 90. That notwithstanding, I actually think data revenues in the quarter including the 2 acquisitions, will be north of $515 million. And so that expenses that I mentioned in the earnings script will be more than offset by revenues, and then obviously that adds to our overall data business and gives us an opportunity as we combine those 2 companies over time.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then, Jeff, just on the M&A side. So you mentioned the, I guess, issues with Trayport, the process of going through the basically revisiting and giving your side of the outlook. And then on, it sounded like based on your commenta
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then, Jeff, just on the M&A side. So you mentioned the, I guess, issues with Trayport, the process of going through the basically revisiting and giving your side of the outlook. And then on, it sounded like based on your commentary, on the outlook that there could be potential opportunities in certain firms do less in the U.K So just wanted to get your updated view on the M&A opportunities in the space versus and particularly given some of the regulatory hurdles versus what you guys can continue to do on paying down debt, buybacks, just going forward?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a very good question. I mean, holistically, when we look around at our space, we really see that there's 1 company that stands out, which would be a great acquisition, which is our own stock. And so we -- Scott moved very quickly to get back into the
componenttext: It's a very good question. I mean, holistically, when we look around at our space, we really see that there's 1 company that stands out, which would be a great acquisition, which is our own stock. And so we -- Scott moved very quickly to get back into the market and on this call announced that he's actually in the market now, that we started our share repurchase program. If you look at the futures space globally, it's relatively flat year-to-date on volumes. If you look at the a lot of the other trading and clearing spaces, they're down substantially. But yes, our company is actually growing. And you couple that with this segment that we have, our largest segment, which is really growing, in the trading and actually in the data and connectivity space. Scott mentioned in his prepared remarks that we see next year the growth we have visibility because we're signing contracts right now that extend well into next year and beyond for many. The -- we have visibility into the growth of our data business, and so we think the penetration of our stock is just off relative to our peers. And so that's been our focus, and that's why Scott decided to disclose that we actually got in the market earlier than what I think a lot of people suggested.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you guys announced some enhancements to NYSE connect for listed company in September. I think there was some additional in October, and there seems to be in that some of your Investor Relations team, finance team. So I was hoping you could walk through
componenttext: So you guys announced some enhancements to NYSE connect for listed company in September. I think there was some additional in October, and there seems to be in that some of your Investor Relations team, finance team. So I was hoping you could walk through that offering because it seems like it's an area of focus for some of your competitors as well. So what should we really expect here? And then what kind of maybe additional investment might you need to do there or any potential acquisitions that look interesting?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a very good question. So first of all, NYSE has, when we acquired the business, had a desktop that we provided to corporate treasurers and CFOs. It also has some communications tools that it uses to talk holistic companies so the listed compani
componenttext: Sure. It's a very good question. So first of all, NYSE has, when we acquired the business, had a desktop that we provided to corporate treasurers and CFOs. It also has some communications tools that it uses to talk holistic companies so the listed companies can provide updates on various corporate actions and what-have-you as a requirement to the exchange. We decided to replace that infra structure with NYSE Connect, which is what we talked about. It's basically a desktop and provides trading information. We've been building that out in a space where when we look at the space and particularly following up on earlier questions, there is pressure on some of the spent to lower the price of desktops particularly, and that area of data acquisition the desktop delivery is under a lot of pressure. So having a very low-cost desktop that we can provide to people to give them the basic information they need around at debt and equities has been very, very well received. So in a sense, we're a disruptor in providing such a thing. As you can imagine, we have very good data about where stocks are trading given that we own the NYSE, and we have very good data around where bonds are trading given that we've built out this fixed income platform with a number of acquisitions. And we have very good data around corporate actions for our listed companies since it's a requirement that they get that information to us. So that's a very nice desktop that we can expand on. Right now, we're just focused on our list of companies but we'll see where life takes that offering. It has almost no cost to us in terms of incremental margins. And so it's an interesting tool in an area where there is a lot of pressure to lower cost by our customer base.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just for a follow-up, I think you mentioned a couple of sales within your prepared remarks. Have you broken up the revenues or operating income associated with some of those businesses? Also just wondering if you take a stabilize at the impact f
componenttext: Okay. And just for a follow-up, I think you mentioned a couple of sales within your prepared remarks. Have you broken up the revenues or operating income associated with some of those businesses? Also just wondering if you take a stabilize at the impact for Trayport during the quarter or how we could think about the run rate's revenue expenses for that business as well?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: With regard to Trayport specifically?
componenttext: With regard to Trayport specifically?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: IDMS.
componenttext: IDMS.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so with regard to Trayport, I think what we told you what we closed that deal, Ken, was that the revenues were around $80 million and then it had operator margins of about 50%. I will tell you that business has continued to perform well, and so that
componenttext: Yes, so with regard to Trayport, I think what we told you what we closed that deal, Ken, was that the revenues were around $80 million and then it had operator margins of about 50%. I will tell you that business has continued to perform well, and so that those are the kind of numbers that you should have in your head. With regard to the other 2, I won't want to give a lot of detail on the call today. But suffice it to say that as we look to divest those businesses, we will give you more information. And I'll just give me the what I think you are thinking about in terms of modeling, I'm building my budget with those businesses in and then we will extract them at the moment that we sell them and will give you a number information. Suffice it to say though, Ken, that they're not material in the scheme of things to overall revenues were to overall profit and in fact, I would tell you that the overall profit very material.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, in your forecast, 6% to 7% revenue growth for data in '16. I think just in your comments, you expect similar growth in '17. As part of the growth, part of that growth has been driven by higher growth in exchange data. Can you give us a sense of how
componenttext: First, in your forecast, 6% to 7% revenue growth for data in '16. I think just in your comments, you expect similar growth in '17. As part of the growth, part of that growth has been driven by higher growth in exchange data. Can you give us a sense of how you're thinking about that growth for 2017? And whether the very high level of that exchange data growth can stay and stay at double digits of next year? And if so how do you get there?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, for the question, Ken. The other thing I want to do is I want to clarify one point and so it doesn't get misunderstood. We will have additional revenues in the 2 acquired businesses. We would have grown 6% to 7% without that. So it will help
componenttext: Yes, thanks, for the question, Ken. The other thing I want to do is I want to clarify one point and so it doesn't get misunderstood. We will have additional revenues in the 2 acquired businesses. We would have grown 6% to 7% without that. So it will help solidify that towards the high end of the range. We would have been at 6% this year without it. And frankly, on a constant-currency basis, we would've been above 7% for data even without those acquisitions. But directly to your question, we have had a very strong performance in our exchange data revenue this year. Jeff talked about it on the last call and this call. That's a solid mix of growth in customers and some additional value that we captured as we've sold more data to existing customers. As Jeff said, while there is discussion about prices going up, the price per unit if you look at it in terms of the data that's consumed for the price, that data amount has increased significantly. So a good year this year. We would expect to have a good year again in exchange data next year. I truly don't expect it to be on par with this year. But we have, as Jeff alluded to, seen very strong sales in our pricing evaluation business, if you will, the former IDC business, and that's really what is encouraging us and gives us a good solid foundation to suggest that we could be at least at the same level of growth in 2017 as 2016. So said differently, I would expect a bit more balanced growth among particularly exchange data in pricing and valuation in '17 versus '16, which was benefited a little bit more by the exchange data.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Awesome. And then trailing 12 months ROIC fell to the 7.8% this quarter. I have not been able to fully work through it yet, but basically any comments there? And then you always put in your the ROIC is above your cost of capital. I know you didn't s
componenttext: Okay. Awesome. And then trailing 12 months ROIC fell to the 7.8% this quarter. I have not been able to fully work through it yet, but basically any comments there? And then you always put in your the ROIC is above your cost of capital. I know you didn't say that time, this time, so want to follow-up there as well.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think at this point, Ken, it's just implied that it is we're the only 1 in the space that is consistently doing it. So just under 8% versus cost of capital, just over 6%, we are generating excess return on invested capital every day we operate the
componenttext: Sure. I think at this point, Ken, it's just implied that it is we're the only 1 in the space that is consistently doing it. So just under 8% versus cost of capital, just over 6%, we are generating excess return on invested capital every day we operate the business. And again, that's unique in our space. If you look on an absolute basis, although we dipped to just below 8%, that relates to the IDC business that we haven't even owned for a year. If you look at the trends coming out of the last year before that business, we were on our way back to 10%. We'll start to rebuild that as we move through this year and next. And you'll see a similar trend. And again, even at the current level, compared to the people we compete with, our ROIC compares very favorably. So we'll continue to put it on the chart, which distinguishes us. It will continue to be our about our cost of capital, which distinguishes us, and it will be continued to be above our competitors, which distinguishes us.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from Kyle Voigt of KBW.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: You spoke earlier, I guess, about gaining share in the crude markets and we can see those same trends. But, I guess form a volume side, we have seen some share migrate back to WTI more recently. Any thoughts about the market share dynamics in the crude ma
componenttext: You spoke earlier, I guess, about gaining share in the crude markets and we can see those same trends. But, I guess form a volume side, we have seen some share migrate back to WTI more recently. Any thoughts about the market share dynamics in the crude markets and what's going on with some of the volume shift? And then secondly, also related to I think this time last year you had significant growth in open interest on a year-on-year basis. And I think as of yesterday, I think open interest was basically flat year-on-year. So can you and brand specifically so can you help us think about outlook year for growth in this contract now that you've gotten some price stability in those markets?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So 2 things are going on in our minds in the oil space. One is that WTI is really the contract speculator use, and there has been -- over the last year or so a lot of speculation about where the price of oil should go, $60 going down to $30 will go
componenttext: Sure. So 2 things are going on in our minds in the oil space. One is that WTI is really the contract speculator use, and there has been -- over the last year or so a lot of speculation about where the price of oil should go, $60 going down to $30 will go back up to $50. Those kinds of behaviors particularly as the U.S. was rightsizing its drilling infrastructure and as high yield was in focus on many of the energy companies. And so 1 would naturally expect that WTI, which we also have, would have more trading in that environment. Brent is and remains the contract that most of the energy space uses for hedging. And the nice thing about that is you can see that that's industry continues to use Brent. The second trend that goes on as we have competitors that are paying for order flow. And there are people that in the trading business that if you pay them they will produce volume. And our competitors that do that like to talk about market share and report market share, and there was actually investors and analysts that reward them for getting market share, even though it's destroying value for shareholders. We have a large customer come to us and said, hey, one of your competitors came to us and said that they would buy our business. What are they talking about? They were not talking about to us about lowering our cost. They actually said they would pay us to move to go. And we said, how much do they say they would pay you? In the said, we will pay you anything, name your price. And so with that kind of behavior, you will always find some people that will take up on that. It doesn't bother us that we lose that share because we are primary market. And as you can see from data sales and just growth in our open interest and what-have-you, that people tend to have to rely on the primary market in order to get paid by competitors. So overall trading volume goes up at our volume, which is really the volume of people that want to pay or maybe the wallet share, if you will, continues to go up for us. And with respect to Brent, this will be, we believe, our 19th consecutive year of growth in trading of Brent. I mean, it's almost -- you put a ruler on it, it's almost an unprecedented ability when you think about everything that's going on in the world over that 19-year period. Wars, changes in policy, changes in regulation, financial crises, et cetera. We continue to see Brent just its volumes just marching forward so we're very lucky to have that as the primary market. We are really careful custodians of it. And it's why we're not playing that game of going in and asking customers for much do you want us to pay you to do business with us.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to put a couple of numbers on the points Jeff made, if you go back 2 years, our share of volume was about 53%. This year, it's kind of mid-40s. But back then, our share of OI was a little less than 50%. Today it's 53%. So the OI is being built by com
componenttext: Just to put a couple of numbers on the points Jeff made, if you go back 2 years, our share of volume was about 53%. This year, it's kind of mid-40s. But back then, our share of OI was a little less than 50%. Today it's 53%. So the OI is being built by commercial customers in our markets. And by the way, that doesn't even include our swap to futures products. If you add that in terms of what the comprehensive oil commercials are trading we are the hedging there was, we are the place where thus commercial customers come to trade their oil.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: Our next question will come from Alex Kramm of UBS.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to the market data discussion. I think Jeff and maybe Scott even as well, mentioned the incremental pressure in the customer base and looking -- people looking to reduce cost. So I don't think that's something you talked about so fa
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the market data discussion. I think Jeff and maybe Scott even as well, mentioned the incremental pressure in the customer base and looking -- people looking to reduce cost. So I don't think that's something you talked about so far. So can you talk a little bit more about what you seeing in terms of the spending environment? Are sales cycles getting pushed out? Are you seeing cancellations, clients going out of business? And maybe more holistically, and you look at your data offering, how much of the business to really feel like must-have like the last thing that people turn off when they turn off the light to close shop? And how much is more discretionary spending?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that's great. First thing I would say to you is we see our retention rates, renewal rate between a little visibility into having owned it is input ICE data services together earlier this year. We see our retention rate is very, very high maybe even
componenttext: Well, that's great. First thing I would say to you is we see our retention rates, renewal rate between a little visibility into having owned it is input ICE data services together earlier this year. We see our retention rate is very, very high maybe even increasing a little bit, well into the above 90% renewal rate. So we don't see the pressure, if you will, on those businesses. Where we -- when we're out talking to customers, where we hear there is a lot of focus is on data that's delivered via a desktop, a lot of focus on the number of screens, if you will and the acquisition of desktops. We built the safety network and combined it with a 7 ticks network to build essentially a data plan that is the subject via API. And we see strong growth in people wanting to buy bulk data if you will via an API and manage it internally and not buy it on individual desktop basis. We're not really in the desktop space as I mentioned earlier. We have NYSE Connect, which is a desktop that is a very low-cost desktop and to a certain degree, it's becoming a substitution for the higher desktop providers, if you will. And so I think that's the trend that sort of mixed up here. Alex, I really believe that the middle and back-office in your firm has no choice but to, for compliance purposes and for improving systems and commoditization of the way risk is being looked at insides large firms is buying that bulk data and figuring out how to redistribute it, and I think that that trend is going to continue. Because we haven't really seen the full implementation of MiFID. We have seen the results of different Brexit regime. The SEC is not fully commented Dodd-Frank. And so there are still more pressures for compliance and internal functions that we think will drive demand.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, great. And then maybe just secondly, on the transaction side, particularly on your futures business, I think one of the things that you don't talk about much is pricing leverage. When you look at your with our competitor in the U.S., I think th
componenttext: All right, great. And then maybe just secondly, on the transaction side, particularly on your futures business, I think one of the things that you don't talk about much is pricing leverage. When you look at your with our competitor in the U.S., I think the last 3, 4 years, every year they have given updates on pricing moves that added 2%, maybe 3%. You don't really talk about that much. And I think your pricing is also we more straightforward. But how about pricing in that business? I mean, you can talk about the relevance of your products? And shouldn't you be taken a little bit more pricing over time? Maybe an update on your philosophy there?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, generally speaking, we benefited from keeping pricing relatively untouched and allowing volume to grow. When we think about -- going back to people that pay for order flow and in order to wait market share, we think about the markets slightl
componenttext: Yes, I think, generally speaking, we benefited from keeping pricing relatively untouched and allowing volume to grow. When we think about -- going back to people that pay for order flow and in order to wait market share, we think about the markets slightly differently. We have people really look at market every day and talk to customers and try to say, do we have liquidity all the way out to forward pricing curve? Are there gaps in where people tried to do business and where we have markets and so we will provide incentive programs to try to fill in gaps for to make the market better for our customers. And so we do have incentive programs, which pricing but they are not to get overall market share. They're really to make a better markets. And we found that consistently we've been able to grow by having that philosophy. So to a certain degree we haven't touched the control panel.

componenttext: Scott, I wanted to touch on the margin question. So when you look at the data business, you guys are doing 50%. Obviously, markets up since you acquired IDC. Where do you guys see the market is going over time? I understand this can be function of the revenue growth as well as the expense synergies that you are yet to come out. But bigger picture, with the profitability in that business ultimately get closer to where the transactions of other businesses?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, look, I do want to predict an end state, but I certainly think there is room for continued margin expansion. And that will come in 2 favor as you just said. We still do have synergies that we will extract from that business. We mentioned originally $
componenttext: Yes, look, I do want to predict an end state, but I certainly think there is room for continued margin expansion. And that will come in 2 favor as you just said. We still do have synergies that we will extract from that business. We mentioned originally $150 million. We'll do 65 this year, well above what we thought it would get done in the first year. But those synergies will continue to come out and improve margins. The other thing that I talked about a little bit that I think it's really important for people to understand, the incremental margin on the proprietary data we sell is very similar to historically what you've seen him in the margins on our trading business, where it's more labor-intensive in terms of just trying to determine what the price of bond is. There are people involved with that versus the oil be decided on an exchange. But once you determine that price of the bond, if I can sell it to a second customer and a third customer and a fourth quarter, the incremental costs are very small. And so revenue growth and price hike with the margins, synergies drive margin improvement, and so I absolutely think the expectation for that business is margin expansion over time. Again, I'm not going to guess what the end state is but it's higher.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, to add on to the prepared comments that I made, what ICE does really well is the use technology to build something complicated and do it onetime and use our network to sell that thing many times. And so the businesses that you mentioned that we're g
componenttext: Alex, to add on to the prepared comments that I made, what ICE does really well is the use technology to build something complicated and do it onetime and use our network to sell that thing many times. And so the businesses that you mentioned that we're going to exit and businesses that we've exited in the past when we acquired NYSE and other firms tend to be very good businesses that are growing, but they don't have the phenomena where we can use our technology skills to build something once and our network to redistribute it. And so for example, we're going to sell NYSE government services, that is a very hot space. It's a growing space companies need more infrastructure to educate employees about anti-money-laundering. There is a huge demand for what they do and that company has -- is going, has growth potential, but it doesn't have that phenomenon that I just mentioned that really we do well. So that's why we say we think that company will be better owned by others. A good company but 1 that doesn't cater to our needs. We tend to see other people in our space go into those kinds of businesses. But we just don't do well and it doesn't really work for us to be in these lower-margin consultancy type businesses.

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, makes sense. And just a quick follow-up on the capital return dynamic. You guys talked about in the past running probably a little bit higher leverage then you have targeted in the past, maybe an update there, was kind of the debt-to-EBITDA ratio
componenttext: Got it, makes sense. And just a quick follow-up on the capital return dynamic. You guys talked about in the past running probably a little bit higher leverage then you have targeted in the past, maybe an update there, was kind of the debt-to-EBITDA ratio as we should be thinking about a go forward basis and we try to can through the buyback over the next year or so?

headline: Intercontinental Exchange, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So you're right, historically, we've talked about 1.5x and we've more recently talked about the need to get below 2x. And that remains the objective. We are on a path to do that. That's why we were able to get back into the market in October and take
componenttext: Yes. So you're right, historically, we've talked about 1.5x and we've more recently talked about the need to get below 2x. And that remains the objective. We are on a path to do that. That's why we were able to get back into the market in October and take advantage of what Jeff correctly identified as the best buy in the market in our opinion. So we definitely are on a path to get below 2x. We're committed to get there. But as I said in my prepared remarks, not only we were able to restart our buybacks in October, but we remain committed to grow our dividend as we grow. And I think, with the increased cash generation that you're seeing, we're going to be north of $2 billion of operating cash flow this year, well north of probably $1.7 billion of free cash flow this year. And that should definitely allow us to get our leverage back below 2x to continue to ramp up our share repurchases because we certainly are at the level in the fourth quarter that we would anticipate being as we move through next year then also to grow the dividend as we grow. All of which hopefully move us. In '14 and '15, we returned almost $1 billion a year. This year, it will be between $400 million and $500 million but I said I think as you get into '17 and certainly '18 and '19, you're going to see us get back to and above the levels you saw in '14 and '15.

componenttextpreview: Well, the answer the first part of your question is that we haven't looked at the data into what you just described. In fact, we're part of the exercises going on as we're quitting ICE data services is just for management to figure out the metrics that we
componenttext: Well, the answer the first part of your question is that we haven't looked at the data into what you just described. In fact, we're part of the exercises going on as we're quitting ICE data services is just for management to figure out the metrics that we're going to use to run the business. And honestly, it probably won't be as detailed as you just laid out because there's a lot of moving parts particularly given the second part of your question wishes we do see the opportunity because we have a large data set that contains some commoditized data OEM parterre data, some network infrastructure and some desktop space, some indices and some calculation engines to sort of packaged deals, enterprise package deals for people, and there's tremendous interest in that. They -- people can to those deals for the with us. They don't have to have a middleman, and we can provide a range of services. So we've been very successful early on in the ETF, ETP space, where there's a lot of cost pressure on those competitors and yet they need a full range of services from listing the ETF to calculating the ETF to having the prices of the things that are in the ETF to creating index for the ETF and using our brands in marketing to ETF. So using a package deals don't lend themselves to some of the metrics that you just described. So I doubt that we'll ever fully get to that.
